newsitem.title: USA: Horace Mann to exit medical insurance, cut 40 jobs.
newsitem.headline: Horace Mann to exit medical insurance, cut 40 jobs.

text.p: Horace Mann Educators Corp. said Monday it plans to withdraw from the group medical insurance business over the next two years, resulting in the loss of about 40 jobs.
The Springfield, Ill.-based company said it will focus on its core group life and disability insurance lines.

Horace Mann said it will account for group medical as a discontinued operation and expects to incur a $3 million charge in the fourth quarter for severance and other expenses and for operating losses during the phase-out period.
It estimated an after-tax net operating loss of $5 million in fiscal 1996 from its group medical insurance line.
The company said it intends to stop writing new group medical insurance policies in January and stop renewing group medical insurance policies in January 1998.
Horace Mann said its group medical business for 1995 generated 6.8 percent of the company's total premiums written and contract deposits.
The company's stock rose 62.5 cents to $38.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
